titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Woodrow W. Hunter Papers, 1947-1979
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Jeanne Miller and Chris Leonard

did.abstract: Professor of education, and research associate and co-director of the Institute of Gerontology of the University of Michigan. Correspondence, subject files, photographs, audio-tapes, etc., relating to his professional activities, notably his interest in gerontology and pre-retirement training.
did.physloc: Offsite storage, two days notice required for retrieval.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was transferred to the library from the Institute of Gerontology in 1985. Donor no. 6160

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Woodrow W. Hunter Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Woodrow W. Hunter, born March 23, 1913, attended the University of Michigan, earning his AB in Sociology in 1937 and his MA in Sociology in 1941. From 1941-1942 he was an Instructor in Social Sciences at Central Michigan University. After serving overseas from 1942-1946, he returned to the University of Michigan in 1946 and remained on the staff until his retirement in 1978. Hunter began his work at the university as a research assistant and later research associate with the Institute for Human Adjustment. Hunter remained with the Institute through its progression: the Division of Gerontology of the Institute for Human Adjustment and finally in 1965 as a separately-established Institute of Gerontology located at the University of Michigan (Ann Arbor) and Wayne State University (Detroit). Hunter served as Acting Co-Director of the Institute of Gerontology in 1970-1971 after Wilma Donahue's retirement. From 1970 until his retirement Hunter was associate professor of education. In 1978 he retired from the university and was given the title Emeritus Professor by the Regents.

Woodrow Hunter became involved in the field of gerontology in its early period in the 19408. He was involved in a number of projects of significance in the development of this field, such as the 1947-1948 Needs and Adjustments of Older People Study, the Residential Institute program, and the Faculty Seminar in Gerontology. Hunter's most important contribution to gerontology was his research and training in the area of pre-retirement education program for the Upholsterer's International Union. He did extensive training with other companies and unions, and conducted numerous research projects and pre-retirement training programs in the U.S. and in Europe.

His professional involvement included membership in the Gerontological Society, the Adult Education Association, and the Michigan Society of Gerontology, of which he was president in 1967, and which in 1972 awarded him the Harry J. Kelly Award. He was chairman of the Education for Aging Section of the 1971 White House Conference on Aging and was involved in the planning of a number of the University of Michigan Annual Conferences.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Woodrow W. Hunter consist of ten linear feet of material and cover Hunter's thirty-two years (1947-1979) as a professor of education and researcher at the University of Michigan. Correspondence, manuscripts, course notes, data sheets, and files relating to research and training programs are included. The collection is divided into seven series: Correspondence, Training Activities, Research and Project Files, Organizations, Institute of Gerontology, Manuscripts (Not Hunter), and Other Media. Training Activities and Research and Project Files are arranged chronologically, and all others are arranged alphabetically.

controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Institute of Gerontology.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence (1 linear foot) is subdivided into four subseries: General, Personal, Pre-retirement, and Preretirement-Government. Each subseries is arranged chronologically.

Training Activities is the largest series, containing three and one-half linear feet of material. The series is arranged chronologically by year, and alphabetically within each year. The material documents Hunter's workshops, training programs, conferences, and courses, mostly on the subject of pre-retirement training. The files contain correspondence, speeches, course notes, papers, and printed materials. Training done as part of major research projects is located in Research and Projects Files.

scopecontent.p: In general, files on research and other major funded projects are arranged chronologically in the Research and Projects Files series. Common materials include proposals, surveys, training materials, correspondence, and interim and final reports. Files from several significant research projects are included. The 1947-1948 Institute for Human Adjustment study "Needs and Adjustments of Older People" files can be found here. While never published, this study was influential in setting the agenda of the 1950 National Conference on Aging. Also in this series are two pre-retirement education studies, both of which included training. The Upholsterer's International Union Preparation for Retirement Study and Programs (1955-1956) is thought to be the first American educational program on retirement offered through a labor union and may have been the first industrial pre-retirement education program in the United States. The 1956 Niagara Falls program, "Preparation for Retirement of Hourly Employees" was a cooperative effort of management and labor of three industries, and of the community. The Hunter Papers also contain files from the 1963 Cross-National Survey of Pre-retirement Education Programs in Europe and the HEW Region V pre-retirement training project of 1976-1978.

scopecontent.p: In the Organizations series, Hunter's involvement with a number of organizations as consultant, board member, or researcher is documented. The material is arranged alphabetically by name of organization.

scopecontent.p: The Institute of Gerontology series contains files relating to the activities and administration of the Institute. The greater part of the material covers the 1970s, including Hunter's tenure as acting co-director in 1971-1974, and the Residential Institute program.

scopecontent.p: The series Manuscripts (Not Hunter) contains some forty manuscripts of papers on gerontology, collected but not written by Hunter. They are arranged alphabetically by author's name.

scopecontent.p: The Other Media series in box 10 consists of photographs, films and sound recordings of programs and conferences on pre-retirement training and gerontology in general. They include audio-cassettes, reel-to-reel tapes, and 16 mm films.

did.unittitle: Tape 1: Work Versus Retirement: Expectations and Personal Viewpoints (parts 1 and 2)
Tape 2: Food and Nutrition for the Elderly (parts I and 2)
Tape 3: Good Health During Retirement (parts 1 and 2)
Tape 4: Social Security and Medicare (parts I and 2)
Tape 5: University Pension, Health and Life Insurance Benefits (parts 1 and 2)
Tape 6: Legal Affairs of the Older Person (parts 1 and 2)
Tape 7: Legal Affairs of the Older Person (part 3) and Financial Planning (part 1)
Tape 9: Friends, Family, and Living Arrangements (parts 1 and 2)
Tape 10: Free Time and summary (parts I and 2)
"Preparation for Retirement" UM Television (16 mm films; sound, black and white)
1. (Silent) Retired man sitting in the living room and getting in his wife's way as she prepares for some sort of party
2. Retired And Home All Day. Retired husband is sitting around the house while his wife makes ready to have her friends come in.
3. Older Worker And Pressures On The Job. Industrial shop scene: the pressure which an older worker feels trying to keep up on his job.
4. Retired And Living With One's Children. Situations which arise when an older man goes to live with his children.

5. Health During The Retirement Years. Situation in which an older man experiences dizziness and pain in his legs. Provokes discussion of self-diagnosis, fear of going to doctor, use of patent medicine, etc. (2 copies)
6. Financial Planning For The Later Years. A situation in which an older man and wife realize the need for financial planning.
7. The Last Day On The Job. What happens the last day on the job.

8. The 64th Birthday. The 64th birthday and how a man and his wife react. We use this as an introductory film in our pre-retirement planning courses because it provokes discussion of the need to plan, the way people feel about retirement, etc.
